children.text: This is [INTERVIEWER NAME], Today is June 27th 2024. I am here in [COMMUNITY NAME] for an interview with one of our community members. Before we begin, I'd like to get verbal consent for the form we just went over. Could you please say I consent to being interviewed and audio recorded for the study.
I consent to being interviewed and recorded.
Perfect, thank you so much. So first off, can you tell me how you came to live here in [COMMUNITY NAME]?

Uh, my mom and dad, my mom was born in [COMMUNITY NAME]. And my dad was born in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME]. And I've, we've just been here my whole life. We had a little farm out in the country. There's, you know, like say is born and raised. I'd Brothers, and we had a lot of land run around and play on and it was it was fun. Country living.
That's awesome. So we go way back then here with this town.
Oh, yeah.
Perfect. And can you tell me a little bit more about this community? Like, if you met someone new and want to describe this town? How would you?

Uh, well, today, it is changed drastically. Uh, today's standards, I would say, uh, it would be a really nice place to move to because, uh, we don't have real high crime rate. We don't have a lot of, um, gang activity in the schoolers little bit. Our police force stay on top of it. And the people in this town are just, um, they're getting a little bit [INAUDIBLE] we're so overcrowded now that you don't know, some of the people around you, your neighbors, but all of the neighbors that have moved in around us, that are from out of town been, been great people. I mean, they're, you know, nobody, nobody that, uh, you know, won't shoot or anything or have bad words with but you know, it's just, it's a laid back feeling. And it still has that small town, feel sometimes. And then other times you drive through the town and you realize that man is places bigger than [LAUGHS] it needs to be because and it is funny because people it's like we got we got a Walmart, and Kroger decided to go move in, put in a Kroger. And there were people in his town that were just absolutely raising all kinds of static about having another grocery store. And I mean, he goes, Hey, man is different. Good golly, give somebody else a choice. You know, not everybody likes to shop at Walmart or Brookshires. But, you know, it's just politics. [INAUDIBLE] a small town. But uh yeah, as far as living here. I lived in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME]. Working with my job as a carpenter. And I stayed out. When I graduated high school, I thought to myself, Man, I will I want to get out of this one horse town. At that time, there was one red light in the middle of town. And I just don't I want to get out of this one horse town get to big city, and just not ever come back. And I moved. I lived in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] for a little while. I lived in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], lived in West [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME]. And then I moved back to [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] and [CHUCKLES] I had a bullet come through my apartment, one night from three apartments down [CHUCKLES] and that kind of changed my mind and I need to get back to the country.
[CHUCKLES]
Somebody's gonna shoot me I wanted to know who it is,
[CHUCKLES]

and know that I probably deserved it. [LAUGHS] But it's just, uh, you know, it's, it's home. You know, uh, I used to live out in the country. And we moved into town. And, you know, it's still wherever you're at this. That's what I love about this. This town is that you just feel at home. You know, comfortable. It's a comfortable town.

Absolutely. That's great. And I've heard very similar sentiments from a lot of people. So being here for a while and even comparing it to some other places you lived like how would you say the community has changed? You spoke a little bit about that how much it's changed, recently especially.

Oh, well, doing, uh, the trim work and carpenter work. I used to work exclusively in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], and I worked, uh, in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] for years. And my son decided he wanted to open up a construction company, and wanted know if I'd work for him. Yeah, I'd worked for you no prob. And so we started, you know, it's just I drove to [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME]] for years fault to traffic, it was horrible. You know, the people I worked with were great. The company I worked for was great. But it's just it backed then it was it was an hour - hour and a half drive get to work. Now you can get there in 30 minutes because of highways. And, uh, it's just one of those, uh, I don't know, you know, it's, uh, I just got where I hated to drive. And like, say, my son, me and him started doing construction work. And we've just kind of he's built up a clientele centered around his town. And we have, uh, to whip through three big contractors that we work for and build trim houses for just here in this town and in we've got a real good contractor down in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] working out on, uh, the lake. And making this just in my son's got a real good reputation with all the, uh, uh, contractors. And, you know, we tell them, they say, Well, can you come do this for me over here and start this house, now, it's gonna be about three or four weeks, you're gonna have to get somebody else, and they tell us, we'll wait on you. And we know that we're a little more expensive. But I've seen, I've taught my son well. And he's a better carpenter than I am. And, as a parent, that's what you want for your kids, you want your kids to have a better life and be smarter than you. My son is, he's surpassed me long time ago. And I've got two boys, two girls. And boy, the boys were a lot easier than girls like, I still want to beat my head against the wall with my 20 year old.
[LAUGHS]

But now it's it's, uh, you know, things are just it's just a you know, it's it has changed. I mean, we had a population when I was in school, high school, we in round 5000 people. And I'd say now we probably got - what do you think honey - about 20,000.
More than that.

More than that, yeah, we got over probably probably closer to 30,000 people in our community. And reason being I think, is the fact that it is a rural community in a rural life. And that people are going to be attracted to that because like, say it's lower crime rate, lower, you know, there's, you know, there's areas crack houses around, and there's bad boys and bad girls. But I mean, our police department stays on top of it. And you know, it's it, they don't hang around very long. You know. So [INAUDIBLE], it's, it's a great place but a lot of changes. It was like say we used when I went to high school we had one red light right in the center of town. And it wasn't really a red light, it was a red flashing light this way, and a red flashing light this way, you just [CHUCKLES] wasn't even a red light, that make you stop and go was just you stopped. Let the car go when you go. And now there's probably a couple of 100 red lights. You know.Yea
Yeah, a lot of change recently. I've seen so much myself in my short time here. So despite all this change, what would you say are still some of the greatest strengths here in this community?

Some of the greatest strengths. Uh, I'd say the school system is probably one of it's greatest strengths that we've got a really good educational system in place and, uh,I know, when my boys and girls were growing up, uh, the teachers were very involved with us to let us know how our kids are doing in school. And you know, and it's in our school was is I mean, I've had some bad things happen in our school, we've had guns brought school been some lock downs and stuff, some bomb threats. But I mean, you get that anywhere you go. But here is just, you know, it's once in a blue moon. You know, if hardly ever does it happen, you know, and nothing bad has gone down. I mean, there's been a couple of kids that hurt yourselves, and things like that. But, you know, is, you know, I guess one of the other strengths is that we're, we've got three concrete companies that are around [COMMUNITY NAME], we got a steel plant, three concrete plants, there's all kinds of Mazda plant, you know, we've got a lot of business. And there's, it's a good economy here in this town. And, you know, people work hard, and they it's amazing is like me and my wife. You know, sometimes we can go buy product, it's one store, and a new business be opening up. And we will go there, even though it's a little more expensive, just to support and spread our money around the town so that everybody gets a little piece of the pie, not just go to the same store and get the same thing and you know, we, we switch it up and try to spread what little bit of money we do have around other, uh, businesses and you know and we take pride in that.
Excellent. That's very nice. Now that we've talked about some positives, you want to talk about some of the things that you think are negative about this community.

Oh, man. Well, don't get me started on the city council. [LAUGHS] Some of our politicians are - how do I say this - a lot of our politicians are self serving. And they, we feel a lot of people in town feel like they're just looked for ways to spend our tax money. And I mean, it's like, you know, we're, we've always been a pretty meager town. And I know, we grow with the times. But I mean, you know, our, our little city hall and everything. They're building one now that is this huge building. And, you know, everybody's kind of going like, man, do we really need to city hall that big, but then it you know, it's a mixed bag being bad and good, because you're gonna get a huge city hall, the taxpayers are paying for it. But we've got a public library in it. And it's gonna be a big library, you know. And, you know, I think it's great because that gives people that hadn't got access to computers and stuff. And it gives them a chance to go in there and educate yourself or, you know, read a book or you know, in like, say it's count, it's pro and con, there are some things that are good about it. And there's some things that are bad about it. The only other bad thing that I would say about it is the fact that and this this is just my age, telling off on me is the fact that we're growing way too fast. I mean, it's like three years ago when we had the big ice storm. Uh, me and my wife and my sister in law, and my niece and my mother in law, we were all camped out in this house because nobody had electricity. And we had a gas stove and [LAUGHS] I brought the barbecue grill in here, in the middle of the living room, it lit that thing. And we burned the stove. And we had electric heaters in some of the bedrooms, my wife's room. And, you know, it was just because the infrastructure was just, we had rolling blackouts. And you wasn't supposed to be without power for more than about eight or nine, maybe 10 hours. And we were without power for three or four days. And being a carpenter and the projection of this, this area is that they're there, the next 10 years. They're planning on building 400 houses a year. So it's 400 families. And that's supposed to be the trend for the next 10 years. So let's, oh boy, my math is terrible right now. So 10 times 400, that's 40,000 or 4000.
Mhm.

4000. Families. They got to do some with the infrastructure, because it ain't right people to shut their electricity off, or to sell them in, uh, no in the thing with the building. The buildings in the housing is that the city council did and this is like say this is just my age. The city council does not allow anything less than about a $275,000 house. You know, there there are companies out there that would come in and build $150,000 houses if they could. But you know, our city fathers and stuff all "Well, that'll attract the criminal element because I got these substandard houses." Well, I live in a substandard house tell me this. I've got 1800 square feet that's [LAUGHS] in I work on houses and stuff got five 5000 6000 8000 square feet. And you know, and it just amazes me shocked me sometimes that you know what? The value of things has gone up so much. I mean this, this lot, I live on the corner a lot. And when me and my wife bought this lot, my brother we have next door. And I got another brother that lives, four houses down and across the street. And we thought it was cool that all of us get back on the same street, we had a farm that we lived down, whose kids and grew up on. And we kind of got scattered into the winds. And then um, three of us got back together, we lost one brother in a plane crash. But, uh, we all stay connected with each other and we were able to do that. And I don't know of any other. You know, it's I'll meet people. If I'm rambling, I'm sorry, but I meet people in my walk through life. And you know, I just you know, they'll get to be talking about their best friend. And obviously, "Well how long have you known your best friend?" "Oh, man, I've known my best friend. 20, 20 years." "Oh, well cool." "How long have you know when your best friend?" "Let's see, I'm 68. I've known my best friend for 68 years."
[CHUCKLES]

Guy I went to school with but we played together as babies. His mother and my mother would go to the Washateria and wash clothes. It [INAUDIBLE]. They put us on a blanket together. And I know we busted fault with each other and we did it in our adult lives. We've actually threatened each other several times "I'm fixin to knock your head off." But the thing is, we never stayed mad at each other in you know, that's friends, you know, somebody that can forgive you for the stuff you say or the things you do. And that to me, that is probably one of the I know you wanted some negative things but just one of the greatest things that I have got from living in this small town and living here is I've got friends, and I've seen him you know, once a month, twice a month, sometimes, sometimes it's six months. But it's people I grew up with in a know, and yeah it's people I love. And that's the thing with this when we were, I was in high school, man, we didn't you know, you know, seniors pick on freshmen. You know, it's just when we were seniors, we didn't pick on freshmen. Man, we all hung out. I can drink when I was like, 18 if I'm still in high school, and I made some money on freshman [INAUDIBILE] with me, "Will you go buy us some beers?"
[LAUGHS]

"Yeah, sure, man. How much does it cost? Oh it's about $8 A case love getting it for $5 a case" [LAUGHS] It pays for my gas. But and you know, that's, you know, it's luck. Cheapest I've ever bought gas uh was 17 cents a gallon. And uh it's, you know, it ain't that now. And, uh, it's just but, but the love of the people that I grew up with, uh, it's probably been the most amazing and best thing that I've ever had about this town. And like I said we've got that we you know, and one of the bad things about that is, when you get to be my age, sometimes you don't see em until you get to the funeral. And that's hard on the soul. But it, it keeps you in touch to think, with your Creator, that it marks the time that you only got so much time, and you better make the best of it. You know, and it don't matter what situation is, if you're in a bad situation, man turn to you friends and get out of it. You know, unless they're the ones that are causing you a bad situation and you just get away from them. But uh, you know, like I say is there's not anything that's really terrible other than, like, say, sometimes, the infrastructure and just the overpopulation and you look at it, but, you know, I'm a realist to get I know that it's not gonna get smaller, it's gonna get bigger every year. You know, there used to be a lot of country that you could drive back roads and drink beer and never see anybody for hours. And now it's, I mean, it's a solid city. From [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], there's a little bit of country. And there's a little bit of country between here and [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], and from the [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] to [WEST TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] is almost solid cities. And same way going north and south. You know, there's just little stretches of country and just, you know, and it's just gonna grow, it's just gonna get bigger and bigger, more stores, more houses. You know, I guess it's progress. But you know, old guys like me is sometimes it's too much progress.
Absolutely, yeah. And it can be hard for all this change. Thank you.
Yeah.
And you, uh? You spoke about working as a carpenter. Is that correct?
Yes, sir.
How would you say your connection was community influenced your work as a carpenter?
Rephrase it, or just, I didn't quite hear it. I'm a little bit deaf.
Oh, that's no problem at all. Like how would some of the connections you've made with other people in this community? How does that affect your work as a carpenter?

Oh, well, it's it's been great. You look it was like say we've when me and my son started working here local. Uh, we met, we got out and we searched for the con- to general contractors to put our name in the box to "Hey, y'all call us if you need something?" You know, and then we got lucky because well, "How long have y'all lived here?" "Well, I've lived here you know," when I tell I lived here 50 years. And you know, in my son has been here basically all his life. And "Okay, we like local boys" and so we it it has helped us as far as you know, like I say it me and my wife. We try to keep things local in what we do. You know, it's there's, you know, we go out to eat with family and stuff. And I mean, there's lots of great restaurants in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] and [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] and [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME]. And we eat here in [COMMUNITY NAME] to give our money and our business to the fellow people in our town. You know, and there's and there's a lot of people that feel that way, you know, and do that. But, uh, as far as the, the, the how it's helped me as a carpenter, is there have been there's been times when is the little a widow woman over here. And I know she's on a fixed income. And I know she needs some carpet work done. And I get a call. "What would you charge me to do this?" And I go look at it. "I can probably do this for about $700" "Ooh, that's high." "Yes, ma'am." But I said, "I'll tell you what I do. Can you pay me $300?" "Yeah, yeah, yeah." And to be honest with you, it's not that I'm losing money. It's just it, my hourly rate went down. But you got to do what's right. And sometimes you got to take a hit. It helps somebody out over here. And, you know, and then that's, that's kind of paying it forward type thing. Cause, you know, someday it may happen to me that I, you know, I'm gonna fixed income and I need some help. I ain't got the money to do it. And but I know, the trust in God did take care of us, they always had, we, we've been through some really hard stuff with losing family members and stuff like that. And we know that, man, we've had a lot of God, things hit us right in the face. And man, that was God helping us out, you know, you know, and that's another thing about this town. I mean, when I was in high school, we had one high school, we probably had about 20 churches. So and everybody went to church. And so it was, it was pretty religious. You know, there's a lot of religious upbringing, you know, in here in this town, and I think it's a good thing. Because it's like, I don't go to church anymore. But I went to church up until the time I was 19. And I'm 60, fix be 69. So let's be in 50 years. But the older I get the closer to the Creator, become and my faith, get stronger, that I know what awaits me, or I've got a faith in what awaits me. And I'm not ready to go tomorrow. But I'm not scared of when this happens. You know, and that's, you know, and that's, that's another good thing about coming from a small town, small community, is the fact that you can do this, it's you, you get to know your neighbors, and you get to trust them. And I mean, I've worked with people up in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], that I've, you know, I'm working on their house now been there about two, three months and you know, just in conversation. "Man, how are you neighbors, got good neighbors?" "Well, I don't know." "What do you mean, you don't know? They live right next door to you." "Oh, yeah. But we don't talk to them." "How long they live there?" "Oh, we live beside each other for 15 years. You know, we'd wave and say hi, and that's about it." Man. That's once you go over, talk to them across the fence, man strike up conversation. You know, this is just weird, you know? And, I don't know. Let's say I'm a dinosaur, I love being a dinosaur. And, uh, I like coming from a small town. In fact, I'm proud of that fact that I come from this town and I used to hate this town. You know, your perspectives change and, you know, you grow up and you realize that the this place ain't as bad as I thought it gonna be.
Absolutely like what you're saying with the neighbors. It's such a common thing.
Yup.
Especially in like cities where I'm living now. Yeah, I completely relate. That's a big positive.

Yeah. Well, everybody so there's there's so much meanness in the world. I mean, people that just, you know, man, they'll take advantage of you, man, they'll rob you blind or worse. And so everybody gets distrustful. You see somebody, you know, and it's in I've been guilty of this, you know, we profile. You know, you see some guy over here has got a lot of tags, and he bald headed and he's got tattoos all over his neck, his arms, and you instantly think this guy's bad news. And you find out if you get to know him, you find out man, this guy, le, he's a deacon in the church. And he's done all this volunteer work and stuff. You know, and, you know, you realize I've been wrong. But you know, a lot of people won't give it that chance to really know this person. And me and her have done we're proud of the fact that we do for the community and, uh, do what we can we help out for we can, you know, large, she had two boys, my sons when ever I met her, and they became my sons. And then we adopted two girls after our boys got grown. Again, you know, in [INAUDIBLE], man. Hey, hold on, y'all. You know, you got young girls and you raised em and ya'll already raised your kids. You know, y'all y'all, y'all. What are you doing that? [RUSTLING IN BACKGROUND] They're in our village. Ah, you know, I don't have any kids my own. But I did. I got these four. I got ten grandkids. They're not blood grandkids. But they are my grandkids took them home. And, you know, they're gonna be my grandkids you know? Even after I'm gone, you know, so yeah, it looks like that's, that's the type of values that I have learned growing up in this town is take care of the village, you know, reach out there. I can't comprehend. The guy that runs out on his kids, or a woman that runs out on her kids. Or, you know, get get hooked on drugs, and she may just not take care of their kids. And I mean, you know, Angel, I've been down that road too. But I grew out of it. said that's it. Man. I can't accomplish the things in life. I won't if I keep this going. I was 26 I decided it was time for me to dry out and quit being stupid.
[LAUGHS]
Well, I don't know. [LAUGHS] My wife will disagree with you. Oh, man. I still do some stupid shit. [BOTH LAUGHS] Pardon my French.
That's all right.
You can bleep that one out. [LAUGHS]
That's between you. How bad you are.
Yeah.
Back to your work as a carpenter a little bit. How long have you been doing that here in [COMMUNITY NAME].

I've been a carpenter since I've been doing carpenter work since 1972, though, started with my dad, working on weekends and working summers. And then when I graduated high school, uh, I was gonna join the Navy and because my dad was a Navy man, and I thought "Boy, he'd be proud of me for joining the Navy." He's "Oh, no, no, no, no." Because I had a brother went to Vietnam. And I graduated. The wars had been was ending. And so in Vietnam, it was over with and he then you brother, you mama went crazy. When you brothers go on with worried about him, and you're the baby of the family. I don't want you to put me through. [LAUGHS] So my dad had been his partner and he got me in the carpenters union in Dallas. And basically I got a bachelor's degree in carpentry served out in the apprenticeship, one school for four years. And I never looked back. It's to me it's a honorable trade. I mean, you stop and think about it. What did Jesus do to make living? He was carpenter. You know, he was construction, damn construction worker [LAUGHS] is, you know, you just I just, you know, and it's one of those things too that I'm proud of the fact of what I do, I build houses. Because of me people can move into a house and start a new life. And I look at it that way. You know, that? Yeah. I have done something to help the community building houses here. And you know, I just don't know, it's, it's, it's, it's kind of just a big circle, like big wheel that goes round and round. And you know, the mess. That's what I like to say, a swirl early loop about this town, is fact that all almost I say 99% of the people that everybody will try to take care of you. You know, if if you're down. I mean, we had we just had a friend of ours did, had a tornado hit his trailer house. And he's got wife, two little kids. And I mean, they lost it, it just tore his down to the ground, scattered out in pastures. And we got involved with helping them rebuild. And I mean, within a day or two, we'd found em a place to live. got them involved with the church, helping them, you know, [LOCAL CHARITY] and all of this stuff, and helping them get back on their feet. And two weeks later, they were better off. My my friend, he told me, he's meant we're better off than we've ever been in our life. Because you guys, when he met, I just don't understand how you reach out to people, like I said, it's really easy. You do what's right, you know, like I say. See, that's just part of the values that I grew up with. I had two great, amazing parents that instilled that in me and my brothers. I mean, there was four of us. And ain't nobody went to jail. You know, we knew better, you know, not a bad, not a bad one and a bunch. And we made our mistakes. And we, I mean, they, I spent the night in a jail cell couple of times, but never was arrested. Because I was best friend with the chief of police's son [LAUGHS]. And so it was a he get in a car and we'll take you to a bed. And he'd take me down in jail, and we'd drink coffee and eat doughnuts he had happened twice in one year. They said don't don't make me pull you over again. If I do. There will be a record and I didn't you know is okay, I'll straight up. Now quit drinking. [LAUGHS]
You're getting off track.
No, yeah. But, okay.
No, that's all right. And um, so I guess as a carpenter, what does your typical workday look like?

[SIGH] Typical workday, we usually try to be on the job at seven, go home at four o'clock. And it's, it's just there's a lot of a lot of camaraderie with the guys that you work with doing construction work. Well I mean, you form you form relationships that lasts for years. You know, and it's, it's kind of corny, but it's like, it's like having a whole nother family, you got your family at home, and you have a family at work. And this was one of the guy that went through the tornado. He's one of the guys we worked with. And, you know, in all of us, that work with him, helped him out, you know, donate money, or time and to help him get back on his feet. And, you know, it's just, you know, like say is, it's not a small town. People that do this, I mean, when I was working in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME] is the same way. The guys down in there, you didn't know these guys. They're all just rolled as much strangers. But we work together. Some of these guys in [DIFFERENT NORTH TEXAS REGION COMMUNITY NAME], I worked together for 22 years. You know, and obviously you just get this camaraderie and you get this other family that take care of have you take care each other? Well, it's been good.
And you touched on this already a lot. So just like briefly, what do you think? What does it mean to you to be a carpenter, it's community and what brings you satisfaction?

Brings me satisfaction as a carpenter in this town. [PHONE DINGS] I think it's just the pride of what I do. You know, people come, uh, through and they look at the houses, and they would "You work on this house over here?" "Yeah." Man, we went through there and looked at and trim work was just immaculate. And I mean, boy it puffs you up, you know, it's "Yeah, did that, you know, and me and my son did that." And, you know, it's, it's just one of those things that, you know, it's pride and community, is what it really boils down to, you know, you do, and my dad's work ethic that he tried to inst-, and he did instill in me and all my siblings, was the fact that he like dad tell me, when I was working with him. He said, "If you build something," he said, "You build it good enough, in the best you can. And be proud enough of it that you'd put your name up in two foot block letters [COMMUNITY MEMBER'S NAME] built this," you know, and, you know, 69 years old, and we're fixing to be 69. And I still have that pride that I try to do the best I can. I forgot a lot. You know, being old, but it's still the, I want to do the best I can do. Is it as much as I used to do, oh, hell no. But it's been, it's been good.

I've lived in Texas all my life. I was born in Titus County. And when I was five, we moved to a farm near White House, which is uh southeast Tyler. I like growing up in the country. When my chores were done, I'd ride my horse planting trees or hot down to the creek to fish or swim. One time we tied a rope to a limb of a cypress tree, and we'd swing out on a vine. In the spring I'd fly kites and on summer nights we'd catch fireflies, but we call them lighting bugs. Once in a while, we'd have fights with corn cobs or pine cones. In winter, we'd build a fire in the fireplace and pop popcorn and roast, peanuts and pecans. I guess I was a live wire. When I was 19 I went to work in Dallas, and Firestone Firestone Tire company. I didn't like city life and for a long time I'd go home every chance I got mama would always cook my favorite food fried okra, hoppin john that's rice and black eyed peas and pecan pie. We had lots of good times. But going home was not the same now. After Dad died, Momma has sold the farm moved to Tyler. I'd rather be living on the farm right now instead of here in city. But my wife and kids don't understand me when I gripe about city life and talk about moving to the country. My oldest child says Daddy, that's crazy. I'd just die if I had to live on a farm. Almost cried first time she said that. I know Texas is changing. But I try to make sure we don't lose touch with our roots. While we may live in a city, I want my kids to have a good feed, feeling for the land. Have a sense of place. Take pride in being Texans. And if they lose our ties to the land, the price of progress is too high.
Alright, perfect. Thank you so much. And thank you again for your time. I'm going to stop the recording right now.
